comment._content: She is so gorgeous... Jesus, so gorgeous!

comment.author: 31244615@N04
comment._content: I really love to coma back to her, over and over again.

comment.author: 29523042@N03
comment._content: Ah, the days when wrinkles were something to be proud of! If only the elderly were treated with such respect today!

comment.author: 36768248@N06
comment._content: I don't think I want to be on her bad side :)

comment.author: 32484687@N00
comment._content: Lovely bright light. He clothes don't look very comfortable - she looks well trussed up in there - might explain the expression - although it looks like she might burst out laughing. A wonderful picture full of character

comment.author: 34857995@N07
comment._content: I could have sworn I just saw her move.  Amazing photo.

comment.author: 37694459@N02
comment._content: Wow, amazing expression! My first impression of this image is that she must have been a strong and tough lady.

comment.author: 79445422@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called La Belle Epoque ca.1890 - ca.1914 incl. ArtDeco and ArtNouveau, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Note the way she's holding her book, as if to show the viewer the title on the spine. The wristlet on her right hand is quite remarkable. I wonder whether this might provide a clue re who she was. Lots of 'possibles' there if you trawl the digitised newspapers at Trove. This one is my best guess, but it's an absolute guess (see the last obit) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71114714. Yet another beautiful pic.
